entry.title: Re: SAP ABAP RAP : Custom Entities with compositions relationship in a Fiori Elements App
entry.content:
Hi,

Adding this comment for anyone facing the following issue:

  • Parent entity is showing up correctly.
  • On selecting a record, (to navigate to object page showing child entity), the parent entity logic is triggered twice.
  • System never processes the child entity logic. App throws a "short_dump" message.

Solution:

  • During navigation operation, when parent entity is called, it should fill the IO_RESPONSE with exactly 1 record.
  • This record should contain the value for fields used is Child entity for the 'To Parent' association.

Example based on the objects created/used in this blog:

Child entity is using field 'ShipReqNo' for association. So, this field should be filled when navigation logic (for parent entity) is called.

define custom entity ZRK_CE_I_ShipReqItem 
{
     ...
      _ShipReq : association to parent ZRK_CE_I_ShipReq 
        on $projection.ShipReqNo = _ShipReq.ShipReqNo ; 
}

For us, the during navigation, the below IF conditions were returning 'false' and thus no data was being written to the IO_RESPONSE object.

    CASE io_request->get_entity_id( ).
      WHEN 'ZRK_CE_I_SHIPREQ'.
        ...
        IF io_request->is_data_requested( ).
          io_response->set_data( lt_shipreq_resp ).
        ENDIF.
        IF io_request->is_total_numb_of_rec_requested( ).
          io_response->set_total_number_of_records( lines( lt_shipreq_resp ) ).
        ENDIF.
        ...

 Once we changed the logic to fill the association field ('ShipReqNo' - only 1 entry) during navigation, the system started calling child entity logic. 

Thanks

entry.title: What causes a CAP projection on a DB entity to fail after accessing an external OData V2 service?
entry.content:
I have a CAP Node.js project that exposes a single service containing both:

  • Projections on local database tables

  • Projections on an external OData V2 service (via EDMX)

service BookingService {
  entity BookingStatuses as projection on my.db.ValueHelp;
  entity HCMBookingRequestView as projection on External.RequestViewSet
     {
      ..
      ..
      code,
      status: Association to ValueHelps on ValueHelps.code= code
     }
  }

What is happening?

  •  I first access BookingService/BookingStatuses â†’ works fine.

  • Then I access BookingService/HCMBookingRequestView â†’ also works.

  •  Then I again access BookingService/BookingStatuses â†’ Fails with:

    Error: Target BookingService.BookingStatuses cannot be resolved for service SAP_HCM

What could be causing this?

  • What makes CAP think that BookingStatuses belongs to the SAP_HCM external service?

  • How is service context resolution managed internally in CAP when both local and remote projections are used in the same service?

  • What should I check to prevent CAP from mixing up DB and external projections?

  • How can I isolate or reset the context so that local projections are always correctly resolved?

  • Whatâ€™s the best practice for mixing projections on DB and remote services in the same CAP service?

Setup Details

  • CAP version: @SAP/cds 8.9.4

  • External service: SAP_HCM (OData V2, connected via EDMX + destination)

  • Local DB: SQLite (dev), HANA (prod)

Any help or guidance on how to resolve this or how to structure services to avoid this would be greatly appreciated!

entry.title: Unexpected Behavior with Team Filter in Peform Maintenance Jobs
entry.content:
Hello everyone,

Iâ€™m encountering an issue with team management in  the "Manage Teams and Responsibilities for Work Centers" tile.

Context:

Iâ€™ve created a team using this app and assigned members to work centers. However, this setup has no impact on the filters used to view jobs associated with a team.

SAP Documentation:

According to the official documentation:

"If no work center has been specified in the Personalization app, the system considers the team defined in the Manage Teams and Responsibilities app."
(SAP Help Documentation)

So, in theory, if no default value is set in the Personalization app, the system should rely on the team definition from Manage Teams and Responsibilities. However, this doesnâ€™t seem to work as expected:

  • If I use the Personalization App to set a Work Center, the job filter reacts properly.

  • If I remove the personalization and rely only on the team setup, no jobs appear.

Hypothesis and Question:

Iâ€™ve noticed that when HR assignments are made directly at the work center level, the jobs are displayed correctly.

This raises a few questions:

  • Are the teams defined in Manage Teams and Responsibilities (type MAINT_TEAM) implicitly or necessarily linked to HR data or should the job filter work without relying on HR assignments?

  • Is there a configuration step or mapping needed between MAINT_TEAM and HR objects (e.g., position, person, organizational unit)?

Thank you in advance for your insights or any experience you can share on this!

Best regards

You can find more information already in the What's new viewer: What's New Viewer (see 2508 - Insights)

Regards,

Marcel

entry.title: Re: Issue with Adopt UI â€“ "Publish" Button Disabled for C...
entry.content:
Hi,

You may not have a correct transport setup in your development environment. This is the most likely cause. 

Beyond that, you can try the following steps:

  1. Verify Custom Field Configuration:

    • Ensure your "User Remarks" custom field in the Sales Document context is properly configured in the Custom Fields and Logic app
    • Confirm the field is published and active

  2. Check UI Enablement Settings:

    • In the Custom Fields and Logic app, navigate to the "UIs and Reports" tab for your custom field
    • Verify that all relevant UI options are enabled, particularly those related to sales order processing and workflow scenarios

  3. Follow Proper UI Adaptation Sequence:

    • Access the Manage Sales Orders app in adaptation mode
    • When adding the custom field, ensure you complete the full adaptation process:
      • Right-click the appropriate UI container and select "Add: Field"
      • Select your "User Remarks" field from the Available Contents menu
      • The "Activate New Version" button should become available after successfully adding the field

  4. Activation and Publishing Process:

    • Click "Activate New Version" first to activate the current draft
    • Provide a meaningful version name when prompted
    • Only after successful activation should the "Publish Version" button become available

Best regards, Dequan Xu

entry.title: How to retrieve multiple tables at once using SAP Gateway Service Builder
entry.content:
Using SAP Gateway Service Builder, I am implementing Association and GET_EXPANDED_ENTITYSET methods based on the following article.

https://www.sapyard.com/odata-and-sap-netweaver-gateway-part-iv-association-and-navigation-in-odata-service/
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hTNclt8sM2c
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=K0yuFRQRygY&list=PLl_MEz33D2N0NvudI_oxOuRW5XMamXe5l&index=28

entry.title: Re: Canadian Tax Subcondition Type - SD
entry.content:
Table A053 stores condition records for taxes using jurisdiction codes, including condition types like JRC1â€“JRC4. In systems with â€œTest Dataâ€ enabled, SAP preloads this table with jurisdiction codes and tax rates, allowing automatic tax determinationâ€”even for manually configured condition types. Without test data, A053 is empty, so the system canâ€™t find matching records unless you create them manually.

As you would know, each condition type (e.g. JRC1) must be assigned an access sequence that includes table A053. To check this access sequence, go to V/07 and verify that the access sequence for JRC1â€“JRC4 includes A053. If it is missing, you can create a new one and add A053. If you created a new access sequence and added A053, ensure that you assigned this new access sequence to A053 in v/06. Finally, maintain condition record in vk11 so that, A053 will populate with the necessary entries.

entry.title: Re: Delivery should not be Invoiced
entry.content: Configuration Options Business Rule Setup Configure delivery date requirements through transaction rules. You can set up rules that require delivery dates for order confirmations and ship notices [1]. When enabled, suppliers must provide delivery dates on order confirmations and ship notices before proceeding with billing processes. Validation Rule Implementation Implement validation rules that check delivery date fields before allowing invoice creation. The system can be configured to prevent invoice processing when required delivery information is missing [1]. Technical Implementation Approaches User Exit Enhancement Create a user exit or enhancement point that validates the delivery document before posting. This would involve: Adding validation logic to check if the Actual Date field is populated Preventing the billing process from continuing if the validation fails Displaying appropriate error messages to guide users Form Template Configuration Configure form templates with validation settings that prevent forms from being created or processed without required date information [2]. This ensures data completeness before document submission. Recommended Settings Enable the rule "Require delivery dates for order confirmations and ship notices" to mandate that suppliers provide delivery dates [1]. This prevents incomplete delivery documents from progressing to the billing stage. Set up tolerance checks and validation rules that verify delivery date completion before allowing subsequent transaction processing. [1] https://help.sap.com/docs/business-network-for-supply-chain/business-network-buyer-administration/order-confirmation-and-ship-notice-rules [2] https://help.sap.com/docs/successfactors-performance-and-goals/implementing-and-managing-360-reviews/360-form-template-settings

entry.title: Re: Departure country from Supplier for Third party sales
entry.content: One option is to create a virtual plant in SAP with the supplierâ€™s country as its location. Assign this plant to third-party items so SAP picks up the correct departure country. This is a workaround but can be effective if you have a limited number of suppliers; else, the other option is to go with custom validation via BAdI SD_TAX_DETERMINE to override the departure country during billing.

entry.title: Re: Tax recorded in entity where the vendor is not where...
entry.content:
Consider the below options

  • If your tax is related to withholding, you can configure extended withholding tax to post to a different company code. However, this doesnâ€™t apply to VAT or sales tax scenarios.
  • Set up a clearing account in Cocode1 that temporarily holds the tax. Then, use a custom program or allocation cycle to transfer the tax to Cocode2 based on expense distribution.
  • Explore going for custom validation via BAdI like BADI_ACC_DOCUMENT or BADI_FI_TAX_POSTING where the logic can be to detect intercompany scenario and Redirect tax line to the company code of the expense (Cocode2)

@Xiao_Qi_Png , Yes, the users need to have an account in both SAC and Datasphere tenants. entry.title: Re: Create SAP S/4HANA External GL Account Hierarchy within SAP Datasphere using standard CDS Views
entry.content:
@JoelleS the values of all dimension columns that do not correspond to the Node Type, have to be NULL. 

See this part in the following blog https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/modeling-a-basic-hierarchy-with-directory-in-sap-datasphere/ba-p/13575652 

"Take the first line of the table in Figure 6 for example: the Node Type is PRODUCT_CATEGORY.  This means that the column Product ID is not relevant. This column must be of value NULL. If you would for example fill the column Product ID with value JUICE_1, this would also aggregate all bookings of JUICE_1 into hierarchy node 2 (MILK), leading to wrong assignments and aggregated values."

entry.title: Re: Split Customer Invoice and Tax amount
entry.content:
By default, SAP posts the gross amount to the customer account and splits the revenue and tax on the credit side. But your requirement is to split the debit side as well.

Some of the options which you can explore on the configuration side are

 

  • Create a separate customer reconciliation account for tax amounts. Post the tax portion to this account using a substitution rule or user exit during document posting.
  • Define a substitution rule in transaction GGB1 for the FI module.
  • If you're using New GL, activate document splitting for tax items. This allows SAP to split tax amounts across different account assignments.
  • If nothing suits the Business requirement, use a BADI or user exit like BADI_ACC_DOCUMENT or EXIT_SAPLF048_001 to add the required logic during FI posting

entry.content:
Hi,
The rule is as below.
Device is iPhone. 

export default function ReadAttachmentAsBase64(context) {
    const fileData = context.getClientData().FileData;
   
    const filePath = fileData?.localFilePath;
    if (!filePath) {
      alert(' No file path found');
      return Promise.resolve();
    }
   
    return context.readFile(filePath, 'Base64').then(base64Data => {
      fileData.base64 = base64Data;
      fileData.docID = context.binding.DocID || '';
   
      // Update client data
      context.getClientData().FileData = fileData;
       context.getClientdata().filePath= fileData.filePath;
      alert(filePath + " filepath");
   
      alert(' File read successfully\n' + JSON.stringify(fileData, null, 2));
   
      // Trigger upload
      return context.executeAction('/Dev/Rules/App/Attachments/SendToImageStore.js');
    }).catch(error => {
      alert(` Failed to read file:\n${error}`);
      return Promise.resolve();
    });
  }

entry.title: Re: Provision Entries for Fiscal year - TDS not effecting...
entry.content:
By default, SAP posts TDS during invoice or payment transactions. But for year-end provisions, you need to simulate a liability without an actual invoiceâ€”this requires:

  • Special GL indicator for vendor-side posting
  • Correct withholding tax type for provision
  • Document type and posting logic that splits the entry between vendor and tax GLs

On the config side, Define Withholding Tax Type for Provisions, Create Withholding Tax Code and Assign Withholding Tax to Vendor Master and finally, execute f-51 for manual journal entry

entry.title: A record needs to change during go-live over DNS Switch
entry.content:
Dear SAP,

 

We are migrating our existing landscape which are on Azure and installed with VM Physical name.

 

Ampol wants to keep same hostname on the target VMs as well which is also on Azure.

 

During the cutover we want to flush out existing A record and update target VM details as new A record. We intend to use same DNS Server for both source and target VMs.

 

Please suggest any available SAP KB/blog to achieve above migration scenario.

 

regards

 


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: A record needs to change during go-live over DNS Switch
entry.content:
Migrating VMs while retaining the same hostname and updating DNS records is a common scenario. While there might not be a specific SAP Knowledge Base (KB) article or blog that addresses this exact scenario, the general steps involved can be outlined as follows:

  1. Preparation:

    • Ensure that you have a complete backup of your existing VMs and data.
    • Document the current DNS settings and A records for the VMs.

  2. VM Migration:

    • Set up the target VMs in Azure with the same specifications as the source VMs.
    • Install the necessary SAP software and configurations on the target VMs.

  3. Hostname Configuration:

    • Configure the target VMs to use the same hostname as the source VMs. This can typically be done during the VM setup process or by modifying the hostname settings in the operating system.

  4. DNS Update:

    • During the cutover, you will need to update the DNS records. This involves removing the existing A records for the source VMs and creating new A records for the target VMs with the same hostnames.
    • Ensure that the DNS server is properly configured to handle the new A records.

  5. Testing:

    • After the DNS update, verify that the hostname resolution is working correctly and that the target VMs are accessible using the intended hostnames.
    • Perform thorough testing to ensure that all SAP applications and services are functioning as expected on the target VMs.

  6. Finalization:

    • Once testing is complete and everything is verified to be working correctly, finalize the migration process.
    • Monitor the system closely for any issues that may arise post-migration.

entry.title: Re: Additional label printing in the stage of "Release" o...
entry.content:
To enable label printing at the release stage of a production order in SAP S/4HANA; in addition to the existing setup at Goods Receipt (GR) via movement type 101, youâ€™ll need to configure an additional output determination trigger tied to the order release status (REL). In S/4HANA, output determination is handled via BRF+

Define a new output type or reuse the existing label output type. Configure a new condition rule that triggers when Production order status changes to REL and Order type, plant, or material match desired criteria

Go to Manage Output Types app or transaction OPK8. Assign the label output type to the production order. Ensure the form and print program are correctly linked

In BRF+, define a rule that checks:

  • Order status = REL
  • Order type = PP01 (or relevant)
  • Plant = 1000 (or relevant)

Set the action to trigger label print output.

Finally, use user exit or BADI like WORKORDER_UPDATE or BADI_PP_PRINT to trigger label printing. Inside the enhancement, check for status change to REL and call the label print program.

entry.title: Re: Missing Sales Order Reference after integration to S4...
entry.content:
The fact that your planned order in IBP retains the sales order reference but loses it upon transfer to S/4HANA suggests a gap in the inbound mapping logic during the planned order creation in S/4.

It could be that when IBP transfers a planned order to S/4HANA via Real-Time Integration (RTI), the reference to the sales order is not automatically populated in the â€œAssignmentâ€ tab unless:

  • The account assignment category is correctly set (typically E for sales order)
  • The sales order and item number are explicitly passed and mapped during inbound processing
  • The planned order creation logic in S/4 recognizes and links the reference fields

Recommended approach would be to enhance the inbound BAdI CIF_PLANNED_ORDER_INBOUND allows you to enrich planned order data during inbound processing from IBP.

entry.title: Re: Differentiating DSA Violations from Common Moderation Issues
entry.content:
Understanding the difference between DSA violations and common content moderation issues is key to complying with digital regulations and ensuring fair online governance. The Digital Services Act (DSA), implemented by the European Union, introduces legal obligations for digital platforms, especially Very Large Online Platforms (VLOPs), to manage systemic risks and illegal content transparently.

A DSA violation typically refers to a failure in meeting the lawâ€™s requirementsâ€”such as not providing transparency in moderation decisions, failing to allow user appeals, or not removing illegal content (e.g., hate speech, misinformation, child exploitation material) within a reasonable timeframe. These violations can result in audits, penalties, or platform restrictions.

In contrast, common moderation issues are day-to-day operational concerns that platforms handle internally. These might include spam, offensive language, off-topic posts, or minor breaches of community guidelines. While these are important to manage, they donâ€™t necessarily equate to legal noncompliance unless they scale or are handled inconsistently without transparency.

What sets DSA violations apart is the legal accountability and systemic nature of the breach. For instance, if a platform fails to offer a mechanism for appealing content removal, thatâ€™s a DSA compliance issue, not just a moderation oversight.

To stay compliant, platforms should implement clear content policies, publish transparency reports, and provide appeal processes. Moderators must be trained to distinguish between internal policy violations and potential legal infractions under the DSA.

entry.title: Re: Do you use the "Group Members" assignment in a Group...
entry.content:
Answer from SAP:

Currently, managing group membership (add/remove) for ALAG groups is not supported via the Admin Console UI, you can only see the group members. This scenario with the managing is supported exclusively through the IdDS SCIM Groups API.

While we understand the convenience of having this capability in the UI, this functionality has not yet been implemented. However, it is under consideration for future improvements. If this is critical to your operations, we encourage you to submit an improvement request, which will helps us prioritize based on customer needs.

In the meantime, please rest assured that you can fully manage ALAG group members via the IdDS SCIM Groups API, and this limitation does not block your intended functionality.

entry.title: Getting Started with Unit Testing in SAP CAP Java Applications
entry.content:
Understanding Unit Testing and Test-Driven Development

Unit Testing involves verifying individual components or functions of a program in isolation to ensure they work correctly. It helps catch bugs early, supports safe code changes, and boosts overall reliability. Automated and fast, unit tests are fundamental to test-driven development and continuous integration.

Test-Driven Development (TDD) is a software development approach where we write tests before writing the actual code. We first create a failing test (Red), then write just enough code to pass it (Green), and finally refactor the code for improvement (Refactor). This cycle ensures better code quality, design, and test coverage from the start.

Benefits:

  • Catches bugs early
  • Improves code quality
  • Simplifies maintenance
  • Boosts developer confidence
  • Speeds up delivery

Getting Started with Test-Driven Development (TDD)

Consider a system with three services:
Books Service: Read-only catalog of books and authors for end users.
Orders Service: Manage ordersâ€”view, create, delete.
Admin Service: Full CRUD for products, authors, and categories.

Each service is focused on a single responsibility, making them ideal for TDD.

For detailed guidance on creating the above described SAP CAP Java application, please refer to the tutorial: https://developers.sap.com/mission.cap-java-app.html

In Test-Driven Development (TDD), we start by clearly defining the expected behaviour of a feature through test cases before writing any production code. This means we write tests that initially fail because the functionality doesnâ€™t exist yet.

For example, when adding stock validation and reduction in the Orders Service, we begin by outlining key scenarios as test cases:

  • Book Does Not Exist: The test verifies that the system throws an error if an order contains a non-existent book.
  • Insufficient Stock: The test ensures an error is raised when the requested quantity exceeds available stock.
  • Successful Stock Update: The test confirms that stock is properly updated when the order is valid.

The test class below uses JUnit and Mockito to define above mentioned expected behaviour for the "validateBookAndDecreaseStock" method in the Orders Service.

package customer.bookstore.handlers;

import static org.junit.jupiter.api.Assertions.assertDoesNotThrow;
import static org.junit.jupiter.api.Assertions.assertEquals;
import static org.junit.jupiter.api.Assertions.assertThrows;
import static org.mockito.ArgumentMatchers.any;
import static org.mockito.Mockito.mock;
import static org.mockito.Mockito.times;
import static org.mockito.Mockito.verify;
import static org.mockito.Mockito.when;

import java.util.Arrays;
import java.util.Optional;

import org.junit.jupiter.api.BeforeEach;
import org.junit.jupiter.api.Test;
import org.mockito.InjectMocks;
import org.mockito.Mock;
import org.mockito.MockitoAnnotations;

import com.sap.cds.Result;
import com.sap.cds.ql.cqn.CqnSelect;
import com.sap.cds.ql.cqn.CqnUpdate;
import com.sap.cds.services.ServiceException;
import com.sap.cds.services.persistence.PersistenceService;

import cds.gen.ordersservice.OrderItems;
import cds.gen.sap.capire.bookstore.Books;

class OrdersServiceTest {

	@Mock
	private PersistenceService db;

	@InjectMocks
	private OrdersService ordersService;

	@BeforeEach
	void setUp() {
		MockitoAnnotations.openMocks(this);
	}

	@Test
	void testValidateBookAndDecreaseStock_BookDoesNotExist() {
		// Arrange
		OrderItems item = OrderItems.create();
		item.setBookId("book1");
		item.setAmount(2);

		Result result = mock(Result.class);
		when(db.run(any(CqnSelect.class))).thenReturn(result);

		// Act & Assert
		ServiceException exception = assertThrows(ServiceException.class, () -> {
			ordersService.validateBookAndDecreaseStock(Arrays.asList(item));
		});

		assertEquals("Book does not exist", exception.getMessage());
	}

	@Test
	void testValidateBookAndDecreaseStock_NotEnoughStock() {
		// Arrange
		OrderItems item = OrderItems.create();
		item.setBookId("book1");
		item.setAmount(5);

		Books book = Books.create();
		book.setStock(3);

		Result result = mock(Result.class);
		when(db.run(any(CqnSelect.class))).thenReturn(result);
		when(result.first(Books.class)).thenReturn(Optional.of(book));

		// Act & Assert
		ServiceException exception = assertThrows(ServiceException.class, () -> {
			ordersService.validateBookAndDecreaseStock(Arrays.asList(item));
		});

		assertEquals("Not enough books on stock", exception.getMessage());
	}

	@Test
	void testValidateBookAndDecreaseStock_SuccessfulStockUpdate() {
		// Arrange
		OrderItems item = OrderItems.create();
		item.setBookId("book1");
		item.setAmount(2);

		Books book = Books.create();
		book.setStock(5);

		Result result = mock(Result.class);
		when(db.run(any(CqnSelect.class))).thenReturn(result);
		when(result.first(Books.class)).thenReturn(Optional.of(book));

		// Act
		assertDoesNotThrow(() -> ordersService.validateBookAndDecreaseStock(Arrays.asList(item)));

		// Assert
		assertEquals(3, book.getStock());
		verify(db, times(1)).run(any(CqnUpdate.class));
	}
	
}

Initially, the test cases will fail (as shown in the image below) as we have not implemented the functionality yet.

Now, let us make the test cases work by writing the functional logic.
The following method is implemented based on the previously defined test cases, completing the TDD cycle by writing just enough logic to make all tests pass.

package customer.bookstore.handlers;

import java.util.List;

import org.springframework.stereotype.Component;

import com.sap.cds.ql.Select;
import com.sap.cds.ql.Update;
import com.sap.cds.ql.cqn.CqnSelect;
import com.sap.cds.ql.cqn.CqnUpdate;
import com.sap.cds.services.ErrorStatuses;
import com.sap.cds.services.ServiceException;
import com.sap.cds.services.cds.CqnService;
import com.sap.cds.services.handler.EventHandler;
import com.sap.cds.services.handler.annotations.Before;
import com.sap.cds.services.handler.annotations.ServiceName;
import com.sap.cds.services.persistence.PersistenceService;

import cds.gen.ordersservice.OrderItems;
import cds.gen.ordersservice.OrderItems_;
import cds.gen.ordersservice.OrdersService_;
import cds.gen.sap.capire.bookstore.Books;
import cds.gen.sap.capire.bookstore.Books_;
@Component
@ServiceName(OrdersService_.CDS_NAME)
public class OrdersService implements EventHandler {

	private final PersistenceService db;

	OrdersService(PersistenceService db) {
		this.db = db;
	}

	@Before(event = CqnService.EVENT_CREATE, entity = OrderItems_.CDS_NAME)
	public void validateBookAndDecreaseStock(List<OrderItems> items) {
		for (OrderItems item : items) {
			String bookId = item.getBookId();
			Integer amount = item.getAmount();

			// check if the book that should be ordered is existing
			CqnSelect sel = Select.from(Books_.class).columns(b -> b.stock()).where(b -> b.ID().eq(bookId));
			Books book = db.run(sel).first(Books.class)
					.orElseThrow(() -> new ServiceException(ErrorStatuses.NOT_FOUND, "Book does not exist"));

			// check if order could be fulfilled
			int stock = book.getStock();
			if (stock < amount) {
				throw new ServiceException(ErrorStatuses.BAD_REQUEST, "Not enough books on stock");
			}

			// update the book with the new stock, means minus the order amount
			book.setStock(stock - amount);
			CqnUpdate update = Update.entity(Books_.class).data(book).where(b -> b.ID().eq(bookId));
			db.run(update);
		}
	}
}

We can now re-run the test cases to ensure the implementation satisfies all defined scenarios and that all tests pass successfully.
As per the TDD cycle, this is also the stage to refactor the code, improving readability and structure without changing behaviour.

Testing the Code Coverage
Following the implementation of the logic using the TDD methodology, code coverage has been assessed using the JaCoCo plugin, as illustrated in the image below.

Conclusion

This guide helps you in getting started with writing and organizing tests, mocking dependencies, and enhancing code reliability in SAP CAP Java applications. With these core practices in place, you're well-prepared to develop and maintain robust, testable SAP CAP Java solutions.

I appreciate your feedback and we will make sure to continue sharing interesting topics.
 
Kind regards
Margit

entry.title: How do I export the results for Import Performance Goal instead of viewing the long email?
entry.content:
Hi Experts,

Is there a way to export (csv) the results from Import Performance Goal instead of viewing the long email of results?

The results look like this and it would be easier to scan if it could be in csv

Row Number:1
Successfully processed.
Row Number:2
Successfully processed.

and so on...

SAP SuccessFactors Performance & Goals
